turns.speaker: ROSASHARN
turns.text: Maybe it's nice on the other side. Them pitchers--them little pos'cards-- they was real pretty.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Aw, sure. This here's jus' a part of it. Ain't no sense a gettin' scairt right off.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Cut it out, Pa. He'p Al with the truck.  Don't fret, honey. You goin' to be awright.

turns.speaker: ROSASHARN
turns.text: Tom, I jus' don't feel like nothin' a tall. Without him I jus' don't wanta live.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Maybe he'll be back. We'll leave word for him. Jus' don't cry.

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: This here's the desert an' we're right in it!

turns.speaker: WINFIELD
turns.text: I wisht it was day.

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: Tom says if it's day it'll cut you gizzard smack out a you.  I seen a pitcher once. They was bones ever'place.

turns.speaker: WINFIELD
turns.text: Man bones?

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: Some, I guess, but mos'ly cow bones.

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: Git up. I got sump'n to show you.

turns.speaker: WINFIELD
turns.text: Whatsa matter?

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: It's them white things, made outa dish-stuff, like in the catalogues!

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: Come on. Ain't nobody gonna say anything.

turns.speaker: WINFIELD
turns.text: Won't they ketch us?

turns.speaker: WINFIELD
turns.text: Lemme go! I didn't go to do it!

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: Keep qui'te, will ya! Shet your mouth!

turns.speaker: WINFIELD
turns.text: I never knowed it! All I done was pull that string!

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: Lissen. You done busted it. You hear?  But lissen here. I won't tell nobody, y'understan'?

turns.speaker: WINFIELD
turns.text: Please don't.

turns.speaker: RUTHIE
turns.text: I won't--  --if you won't tell what *I* done!

turns.speaker: WINFIELD'S VOICE
turns.text: What's these?

turns.speaker: RUTHIE'S VOICE
turns.text: Well, I reckon you *stan'* in them little rooms--an' water come down outa that there little jigger up there--take a bath!

turns.speaker: WINFIELD'S VOICE
turns.text: Jes' like in the catalogues, ain't they!

turns.speaker: RUTHIE'S VOICE
turns.text: I seen 'em b'fore you did.

turns.speaker: WINFIELD'S VOICE
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: RUTHIE'S VOICE
turns.text: Now don't you go monk'ing--

turns.speaker: RUTHIE'S VOICE
turns.text: Now you done it! You busted it!

turns.speaker: WINFIELD'S VOICE
turns.text: I never--

turns.speaker: SPENCER
turns.text: Morning.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Morning.

turns.speaker: SPENCER
turns.text: You people looking for work?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Mister, we're lookin' even under boards for work.

turns.speaker: SPENCER
turns.text: Can you pick peaches?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: We can pick anything.

turns.speaker: SPENCER
turns.text: Well, there's plenty of work for you about forty miles north, this road just outside Pixley. Turn east on 32 and look for Hooper's ranch. Tell 'em Spencer sent you.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Lotta these little farmers mighty nice fellas. Trouble is they're little, they ain't got much say-so.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Shore looks like my lucky day, anyway. Gettin' some work at las'.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: You sure you got ever'thing ready?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ain't gonna be no trouble.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: You ain't to hurt them fellas.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Awright. An' if she gets outa han', I'll be in the right han' corner, this side the dance floor.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ain't gonna get outa han'.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But wait. I still don't understand what you do.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I work at Kentucky Fried Chicken.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You do not.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yes I do.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You don't...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: In the corporate offices.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Oh... really?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: What do you do?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I sell biscuits to the Southland.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You do not.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's what I do.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You're so funny...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I sell biscuits and gravy all over the Southland--

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: --Stop it--

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You know those horsey biscuit gravy packets? I move all of those--

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: --No.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Sometimes we sell them to McDonald's and just change them to special barbecue sauce.

turns.speaker: ARLENE
turns.text: Welcome back! I'm Arlene Oslott- Joseph.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'm Martin Blank.

turns.speaker: ARLENE
turns.text: Marty, you haven't changed a bit!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Don't say that.

turns.speaker: ARLENE
turns.text: We had pictures put on, that way everybody knows who everybody was!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Wonderful.

turns.speaker: ARLENE
turns.text: So, what are you doing now?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Whatever I can get away with.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Bob. Bob Destephano.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: I'm Dan. Dan Koretzky.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Computer guy.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Yeah... Hey, I saw you at your dad's dealership the other day.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I sell BMW's. What do you do?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Not much, actually. My software company just went public so I'm just... hanging out, really.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Remember high school?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Sure. Listen. Why don't you join us up in the grandstands?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Bob...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's me. Martin Blank.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Really...? So what?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Okay. See you later.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: So. You and Debi. Gonna hit that shit again?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Fine, Bob. How are you?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Never better.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Ahhh... it's all fucked up. Nothing adds up to nothing... you work your whole life, day in and day out-- try to make sense of it all. One day you're twenty-seven and what do you get to show for it...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You could've been a contender, huh?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: What am I gonna do?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I want to be an actor.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Then express yourself, Bob.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: I'd come to the realization that everything I'd based my life on was false. And that my life had no meaning.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #2
turns.text: He gets this way when he hits over eighty-five.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: It seemed like my life was slipping away, somehow. I was a knot in the middle of a wet rope. Everything was futile and nothing had value.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: That's a tragedy. Can I finish my story please? I began my search for meaning. I was a Catholic, Jew, Scientologist, Sufi, Buddhist. I went to a Psychologist, psychiatrist, herbalist, nutritionist, a shaman, and a psychic. And they all pretty much say the same stuff.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #2
turns.text: A Jew, a shaman, and a herbalist are telling you the same thing? You're insane.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: Basically the same thing. In a very evolved, esoteric way.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #2
turns.text: Insane.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: To make a long story short...

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #2
turns.text: Jesus...

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: Overflowing with love.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Oh I see. You got your individual slices of hope, dignity, confidence, self-love, justice, and harmony.

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: You open 'em up and there's the sayings, stories, little bites of insight. It's the P.P.P. Six Day Week.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: So you eat-- read it everyday?

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: And these pan pizzas have opened up the doors to heaven?

turns.speaker: CLUB MEMBER #1
turns.text: Correct.  That's for you. Keep it.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: I just play my own collection.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's nice to see you again.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: How long has it been?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Since you stood me up on prom night and vanished without saying a word?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Ten years, I think. What I miss?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Well, let me see... they tore down the George Orwell monument and put up a bust of George Michael. Main Street's a four-laner, no left turns four to seven. I was married and divorced. And Grosse Pointe is now officially the new sister city to Lower Hutt, New Zealand. We have fiber-optic town meetings every two months.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Here is now there. There is here.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Tell me about yourself.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'm in California most of the time. Traveling a lot on business. That's about it, really.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: That's it?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Not much else.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: What's your business?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'm a professional killer.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Professional killer. Do you get dental with that?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Well, I gotta go. But I'll come back.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: All right mystery man. I want some answers. Let's recap. Spring of '84. Two young lovers with frightening natural chemistry. The girl sits in a seven-hundred dollar prom dress at her father's house waiting for the most romantic night of her young life. The boy never shows up, until now. So, what's the question?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Where have I been?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: More like what happened? What happened, Mr. Blank?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I don't know exactly. I could venture a guess but it would sound like a rationalization... I thought you know... maybe seeing you, some friends, my house... of course now a 7-11--

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: --Torn down in the name of convenience--

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: --and I guess, sure, seeing you would be part of that whole equation... I suppose the most important thing, really. I don't know. Anyway, this whole thing's my therapist's idea. It's my shrink, really.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Ohhh. You're in therapy too, Marty?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You see someone?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Uh, no. So you're back now, a decade later, and you want to sort things out with me. The question now is, do I allow you... access... to my being?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Are you going to the reunion?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: No. I'm not going. Is that why you're here?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: That's part of it.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Well, you'll have a ball. You seem to have everything everybody wants when they go back. The car, the suit, the watch. The look. That just leaves the little things, like happiness, character, point of view...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's always the little things.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Okay. Let's catch up. You go first.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Well, there's not much to tell.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: I'm sure you've done worthwhile things in the last ten years. You've had experiences.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Bad experiences.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: You met people.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Bad people.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Watched television?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Bad television.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Jesus. Marty. You're pathetic. It sounds like you need a Shockabuku.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: It's a swift spiritual kick to the head that alters your reality forever.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: That'd be good.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I figured I could pick you up tomorrow around seven o'clock.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Let me get this straight, are you asking me out?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Unbelievable.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Seven it is.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: I'll think about it.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Are you there?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Pick me up at my father's house at around seven. And don't be late this time.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Hello...?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: This night, this reunion will be an important step in our relationship.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: You're fucking psycho.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Don't rush to judgement until all the facts are in.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Flowers. That's funny.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: As long as I get the laugh.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Here. Let me put these in some rubbing alcohol.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You look beautiful.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Okay... Hold on...

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: ...Let me get my coat.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'll just help myself to a cocktail.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Do you want to get a drink first?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: I think they'll probably have booze there.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Shoulda brought my gun.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: --Yes. Actually we just bought that little Frank Lloyd Wright on Pine Avenue... Debi's a social worker and I mow down insurance claims at Aetna--

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: We haven't seen each other since high school.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Which would you rather...?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Okay... Would you rather... commit yourself sexually to a four-by-nine cell with former President George Herbert Walker Bush dressed as a super-model for a month, or make love to a otter on crank for a week?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Soft. I'll take the junkie otter, clearly! I'd let the little beast scratch and claw all he wants... Okay. Would you rather make love to the candied corpse of Phyllis Diller--

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: --She's not dead---

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: It's just a game...! Alright. Candied Diller, or... wear a hot pork vest across the desert with a fully digested crab apple in your mouth?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Wow. I have to give this some thought.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: No time.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Okay, then. Clearly candied Diller.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Even though I left, you never left me. Not just memory but a substance in my blood.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Like heroin?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Too junky-kitschy. Deeper, deeper.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Like love?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Could be. The physical substance of love.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: He was trying to kill you, right!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Not the other way around...?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Is it something you've done?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's something I do...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: ...About five years now.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Get the fuck outta here.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Seriously, when I left, I joined the Army and took the service exam. They found my psych results fit a certain profile. A certain "Moral flexibility" would be the best way to describe it... I was loaned out to a CIA- sponsored program. It's called "mechanical operations." We sort of found each other...

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: You're a government spook?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I was, but no... yes... I was before, but now I'm not. It's irrelevant, really. The idea of governments, nations, it's mostly a public relations theory at this point, anyway. But I'll tell you something, until about five months ago, I really enjoyed my work.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Jesus Christ!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Then I started losing my taste for it. Which usually means your time is up. But then I realized it was something entirely different... I started getting the sneaking, dark suspicion that maybe there was... meaning to life.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Okay. Great, Martin, that's just great. Meaning to life... Mmm....

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Like, that there's a point? An organic connection between all living things.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Let me help you along, Martin. You're a sociopath!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: A sociopath kills for no reason. I kill for money.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: You never could have kept this from me.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I was leaving.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: That's probably a good idea.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Will you come with me?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: I'm staying here.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: What if I come back?

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: I'll hide.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: You don't get to have me. You are a monster, I'm a human being. We're not going to mate.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You don't understand...

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: That's because I speak human, and you speak monster.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: You kill people.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I have no illusions about the future. What is, is. We make choices. And we become the sum total of our choices. I can live with that.

turns.speaker: DEBI
turns.text: Other people can't.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: Why don't you want to go to your high school reunion?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's in Michigan. Honestly, what do I have in common with those people? Or with anyone?

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: You went to school with these people.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Come on.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: We've spent a lot of time discussing those years. Remember we said that fear is a transfer of the bodily hurt associated by experience with the thing feared, to the thought of the thing. Thus we fear a dog without distinctly imagining its bite.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Shouldn't you be taking notes?

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: Tell me about your vision of the reunion.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I just know.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: Say more.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: They'll have husbands and wives and children and houses and dogs.... made themselves a part of something. And they can talk about what they do. What am I going to say?  "I killed the President of Paraguay with a fork."

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: You needn't be so frank with me about your work.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Why not. I trust you. You couldn't turn me in because of Doctor-Patient privilege... and I don't want to be "withholding"... and I know where you live.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: You know where I live?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: We're both professionals, Oatman.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: I think what you fear Martin is domesticity. It's the greatest fear that men have who belong to Western Culture. It's centuries old. Like King Phillip, in the 11th or 12th century who decided one day that he was so bored with his dreary life at home with his wife he thought, "Well, wouldn't it be great if we hit the road and fought... oh... the Saracens."  So he put the word out and was amazed when a million men signed up and all of them wanted to go and fight in distant lands and do terrible things to people rather than stay at home with their families.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: So you're saying that Ulysses-- everything he said to his queen when he came back--everything was a lie? He just wanted to fuck around?

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Mmm.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: And how have you been feeling about your... work lately?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Uneasy. Dispassionate. Bored. It's just getting hard to go to work in a good mood. I'm starting to think I've been in the business too long. Last week I did a guy younger than me.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Anyway, that never use to happen. I was always the prodigy. Now I'm just one of the guys.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: Maybe some of the discomfort you're feeling is... guilt. Remorse. Over the innocent people you've killed.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: If I show up at your door, chances are you did something to bring me there. I don't care about that stuff, anyway.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: What stuff?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Morality.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: Go to your reunion, Martin. See those people and discover what they mean to you. Try not to kill anybody for a few days, see how you feel.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: If I get antsy I'll kill a few small animals.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: What else? Say more.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Saw my mom... I'm with Debi, and I'm on my way to the reunion.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: Okay. Repeat this after me.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Out Loud?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: ...I am at home with the me. I am rooted in me, who is on this adventure.

turns.speaker: DR. OATMAN
turns.text: Take a deep breath and realize, that this is me breathing.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: This is me breating.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: How was your day, today, sir?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Effective. But to tell you the truth, I've lost my passion for work.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Do you like the people you work with?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I work alone.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: That's it then. That's it. I've always been alone. That's why I'm a good driver. I can handle it. See, I can think on my feet. I survive, I'm a thinker. And I can sit there in front of your house for two hours and it don't bother me. Some people can't do it! Some people are ranting and raving, "Tell them fuckin' people to get out here and get in this car, I can't-- I want a go!" Where you gonna go? You're gonna wind up back in your garage at seven o'clock at night. You ain't going nowhere. You leave your house in the morning you get back to your house in the evening. What's the big deal, right?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You understand the psychology of the job.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: I do. Some guys can't adjust to it; they can't handle it.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: You look like you're far away. Far away and thinking about other things. I'm right about that, aren't I?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Well, let's just say that sometimes I'm right. Sometimes you are.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Sometimes I am. Sometimes. It's only natural.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: It's only natural....

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: I been looking at you, and I've decided that I want to share something with you.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Because your problem is you're bored. And you have a very big mind.  I am part of what I call a brain syndicate.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: I am part of a network of minds, a group of five people who are all connected, over hundreds, even thousands of miles, through the mind. We can think with each other, think for each other. I can be driving somewhere, sleeping with a woman-- whatever it is-- and at the same time be thinking a thought in someone else's mind, far away. Running someone else's brain.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Up on the right.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: And when you think of it, it's not so surprising that a small group of people control the whole world, is it?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: I'm setting up a concern that would enable those of us in our rarefied profession to consolidate our efforts.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Like a union?

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: Like a club. Work less, make more.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Thank you, no.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: We could be working together, making big money, killing important people... I'm willing to let you in on the ground floor.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: And you could be... sort of like... a father figure to me....

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: It's a free-market evolution. You'll wake up to it... c'mon Kid. We used to run together when you were a rookie. I don't want to run against you. This thing's real. Everybody's in.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Not me. So don't paw at me with your dirty little guild.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: I'm gonna get you, kid.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: I want two eggs poached, hash brown well-done. English muffin for the bread. And a coffee.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Whole-grain pancakes. And an egg- white omelette.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: Come on, live a little. I'm sorry about the incident yesterday.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: No harm no foul.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: A little misunderstanding among my associates.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: I told them to kill you and they didn't.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Hard to get good help these days.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: But since we're both here, I think it's time to take a fresh look at our relationship.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I didn't get into this business to have "associates." And I don't want to join your Goddamned union. "Loner-- " "Loner gunman." Get it? "On my own." That's the whole point. Why don't you become a cop, or something. You can drink coffee in the morning... with friends!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: No deal.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: Fine. But we're not going to let you do your job. Because we're gonna do it. And then, after we do your job, we're gonna do another little job...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Is that right?

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: Yeah-- after I shoot you through the fucking forehead I'm gonna fuck you in the bullethole.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Nice talk, Sugarmouth.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's okay. It's Martin The door begins to open revealing Debi and Newberry.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I know what I do isn't moral, per se, but if you could just look past that, you'd see a man worth loving.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: Don't listen to him, he's a professional.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: ...How about I sell you two rounds for a hundred grand a piece?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: There you go. I left it blank.

turns.speaker: GROCER
turns.text: Excellent. Here they come.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Hey, Ken. How have you been?

turns.speaker: KEN
turns.text: Hello Martin. How have you been?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Not bad. You?

turns.speaker: KEN
turns.text: Hello, Bob.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Hey, Bob.

turns.speaker: KEN
turns.text: I'm an attorney. I'm with Moss, Brice & Fromeyer.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: That sounds pretty interesting...

turns.speaker: KEN
turns.text: Sometimes. I'm in divorce, mainly. Some property. Some personal injury.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Those all seem kind of related...

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Well... I have to take this over to Debi.

turns.speaker: KEN
turns.text: Here. Take my card. Wait a minute... here's a special one. For top-shelf clients.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Have you seen Debi Newberry?

turns.speaker: KEN
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: KEN
turns.text: The more things change, the more they Goddamned well stay the same.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: You always say that. You always say that. I'm telling you, you never met the man.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: Seventeen months ago I was posting a walk in Lisbon, and he was there. He never saw me. But I saw him, though.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Lisbon?

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: In Portugal, yes.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Here's the news: He hasn't been in Portugal since '90. I know that from the file. Why don't you read the file, man?

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: In fact, I think I talked with him, in Bonn.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Well, remember when Frysal's men paid off the Deejay in Cairo to announce a bogus press conference in the --

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: --Nooo--

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: --Yes. And the Munich Olympics in '72. A local radio station started broadcasting news of the massacre two minutes before it happened.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: That's strictly Bàader-Meinhof stuff.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: It was the PLO.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: Whatever.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: I wish he'd do his job already so we could do our job.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: We can't do our job unless he does his job.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: Why don't we just do his job then, so we can do our job, and get the fuck out of here.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Do his job? I'm not a cold-blooded killer.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: Wait a minute--

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: -Look. You want to kill a Good Guy, but not be a Bad Guy, you wait until a Bad Guy kills the Good Guy, and then you come in and kill the Bad Guy, and then you're the Good Guy.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: So if we do his job, we're the bad guys. If we do our job, we're the good guys.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: He's falling for her. Look at him.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: He using her.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: You're wrong. Look at his face.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: One cannot love and kill.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: I love. I kill.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: Looks like someone keeps trying to do our job for us.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: If he does our job, he's our job.

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: I get it.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Did you see Blank in there?

turns.speaker: MCCULLERS
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Good. For a second there I thought we were in trouble.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: ...Tell them that's not my problem. I was paid for one job-- the cyclist-- not two. See you tomorrow, Marcella.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: Wait. I have Mr. Grocer for you.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Patch him through....

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Throw that away.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: This?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Don't tease me. You know what I do for a living.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: It's from one of those P.O. Boxes. How was the trip?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Tedious. I now authorize you to throw away all personal mail.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: All of it?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: And not show it to me. Ever again.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: That's going to cost.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'll pay.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: They're not happy, sir.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'm not happy.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: They say their friend was suppose to have a heart attack and die in his sleep.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: He didn't.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: They blame you for the compromise.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: And they want me to make up for it.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: In Detroit. This weekend.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Tell them that's impossible. I need my normal lead time.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: They were very upset.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Would you describe their position as inflexible?

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: Intractable, sir. You leave tonight.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: And sir, I also get that broken- mirror, black-cat, Friday-the- thirteenth kind of feeling about this one....

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: There's nothing to be done about it.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: I liquidated the last account in Zurich, and split it into two new ones in Estonia.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Good. What else? Anything interesting?

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: Mmm, not really. But you're gonna love this one.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: Enough?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Never enough.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: But it's a Greenpeace boat. It'd be so easy.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I have scruples. Next.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: Paperwork on the Detroit thing. It's a full dossier. Very comprehensive.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: Don't forget your identity.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: See you next week.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: This is not good.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'll do it tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: What's it look like?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's fine.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: You haven't looked at the dossier.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I've looked at it.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: You have.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yes. It's the same as usual. Nothing remarkable about it at all.

turns.speaker: MARCELLA
turns.text: I have to call the client and give them a reason why you're late.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Tell them my house exploded.
